content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines a "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes by a rental company. It also defines terms like "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard". The term "rental company" refers to a person engaged in renting motor vehicles for rental or lease purposes. The terms "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard" are defined in section 30102 of title 49, United States Code. The term "person" is defined in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. The term "rental company" is defined as a person engaged in renting or leasing motor vehicles, with a fleet of 5 or more vehicles for rental purposes. The term "person" is defined in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles containing safety defects or non-compliance with regulations. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with regulations under section 30118 of title 49, United States Code, unless the issue has been resolved before the transaction. The rental company must not rent, lease, or sell vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with regulations unless the issue has been resolved beforehand. An exception applies if a notification ordered by the Secretary is set aside in a civil action. Rental companies are considered to have received a notification 5 business days after it was mailed. The rental company must not rent, lease, or sell vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with regulations unless the issue has been resolved beforehand. An exception applies if a notification ordered by the Secretary is set aside in a civil action. Rental companies are considered to have received a notification 5 business days after it was mailed. If a covered vehicle during a rental or lease period is found to have a defect related to motor vehicle safety or non-compliance, the rental company must be notified. If a rental company receives a notification during a rental or lease period that a covered vehicle has a safety defect or noncompliance, they must immediately contact the renter or lessee and offer to provide information about the issue. The rental company must contact the renter or lessee and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost if a safety defect is found in the vehicle. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the provisions outlined in the Act, effective 60 days after enactment. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties will apply to those who violate this Act or its regulations. The Act incorporates terms of the Federal Trade Commission Act, imposing penalties for violations. The Commission's authority is not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in federal court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified in certain cases. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in federal court to obtain injunctive relief for violations of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified before initiating such action. The attorney general of a State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action under the Act, providing a copy of the complaint. If immediate notice is not feasible, the State must notify the FTC promptly. The State must provide a copy of the complaint to the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action. If immediate notice is not possible, the State must notify the FTC promptly. The FTC may intervene in the action upon receiving the required notice. The State must provide immediate notice when initiating a civil action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. Nothing in this section shall be construed. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in civil actions, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. Nothing in this section shall prevent state attorneys general from exercising their powers. (c) Construction.--This section does not prevent state attorneys general from using their powers under state laws or from taking legal action in state or federal court for alleged violations. No separate suit can be filed under this section if the same violation is already being addressed in another suit. The attorney general of a State is prohibited from proceeding in court based on alleged violations of state statutes. No separate suit can be brought if the same violation is already being addressed by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include a description of rental companies' buying practices for vehicles lacking these safety features. The report required by the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to Congress within 180 days must include a description of rental companies' buying practices for motor vehicles without standard safety features and their implications on consumer safety, along with recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies that may have safety defects or not comply with safety standards within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects or not meeting safety standards. Rental companies must notify the public if their vehicles are found to have defects or are not compliant with safety standards during a specified period. Rental companies must notify the public about vehicle defects or non-compliance with safety standards within a specified period, starting when they become aware of the issues and ending upon receiving a notification from the Secretary of Transportation or a manufacturer's notice to owners. Rental companies must notify the public about vehicle defects or non-compliance with safety standards upon receipt of a notification from the Secretary of Transportation or manufacturer's notice to owners. The report required by paragraph (1) shall include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles, discussion of the effects on consumers, and recommendations from the Administrator. The report required by paragraph (1) shall include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles, discussion of the effects on consumers, and recommendations from the Administrator. Additionally, a follow-up report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year with any legislative or administrative actions recommended to address or mitigate these sales and effects. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year, detailing any recommended legislative or administrative actions to address or mitigate the sales of covered vehicles and their effects. The Administrator must submit a report to Congress on the sales of covered vehicles, including analysis and recommendations, within a specified period following the initial report. The report required by the Administrator to Congress on covered vehicle sales must include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for the specified period. It should also identify and analyze differences between the findings of the Administrator for the initial report and the findings for the subsequent report. The report to Congress on covered vehicle sales must include an analysis of differences between initial and subsequent findings, as well as a discussion of the effects of the Act on sales.
